title: ICE: string indexed not at a char boundary when constructing error message

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
I'm seeing an internal compiler error on the following input, found by [fuzz-rustc](https://github.com/dwrensha/fuzz-rustc): ### Code ```Rust // ţ must be the last character in this file, it cannot be followed by a newline fn main() { 0: u8(ţ ``` ### Error output ``` error: this file contains an unclosed delimiter --> src/main.rs:3:12 | 2 | fn main() { | - unclosed delimiter 3 | 0: u8(ţ | - ^ | | | unclosed delimiter error[E0412]: cannot find type `ţ` in this scope --> src/main.rs:3:11 | 3 | 0: u8(ţ | ^ expecting a type here because of type ascription thread 'rustc' panicked at 'byte index 4 is not a char boundary; it is inside 'ţ' (bytes 3..5) of `u8(ţ`', compiler/rustc_ast_lowering/src/path.rs:236:49 note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace ``` Affected versions: I tried nightly 2021-11-25 and stable 1.56.1 and they both show the same ICE.
Backtrace

``` Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground) error: this file contains an unclosed delimiter --> src/main.rs:3:12 | 2 | fn main() { | - unclosed delimiter 3 | 0: u8(ţ | - ^ | | | unclosed delimiter error[E0412]: cannot find type `ţ` in this scope --> src/main.rs:3:11 | 3 | 0: u8(ţ | ^ expecting a type here because of type ascription thread 'rustc' panicked at 'byte index 4 is not a char boundary; it is inside 'ţ' (bytes 3..5) of `u8(ţ`', compiler/rustc_ast_lowering/src/path.rs:236:49 stack backtrace: 0: rust_begin_unwind at /rustc/dd549dcab404ec4c7d07b5a83aca5bdd7171138f/library/std/src/panicking.rs:498:5 1: core::panicking::panic_fmt at /rustc/dd549dcab404ec4c7d07b5a83aca5bdd7171138f/library/core/src/panicking.rs:107:14 2: core::str::slice_error_fail 3: ::lower_qpath 4: ::lower_ty_direct 5: ::lower_ty 6: rustc_data_structures::stack::ensure_sufficient_stack::::lower_expr_mut::{closure#0}> 7: ::lower_stmts 8: ::lower_block 9: ::lower_maybe_async_body 10: ::with_hir_id_owner::<::visit_item::{closure#0}> 11: rustc_ast_lowering::lower_crate 12: ::access:: 13: rustc_interface::passes::create_global_ctxt 14: ::global_ctxt 15: ::enter::, rustc_errors::ErrorReported>> 16: rustc_span::with_source_map::, rustc_interface::interface::create_compiler_and_run, rustc_driver::run_compiler::{closure#1}>::{closure#1}> 17: rustc_interface::interface::create_compiler_and_run::, rustc_driver::run_compiler::{closure#1}> 18: >::set::, rustc_driver::run_compiler::{closure#1}>::{closure#0}, core::result::Result<(), rustc_errors::ErrorReported>>::{closure#0}::{closure#0}, core::result::Result<(), rustc_errors::ErrorReported>> note: Some details are omitted, run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=full` for a verbose backtrace. error: internal compiler error: unexpected panic note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug. note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/new?labels=C-bug%2C+I-ICE%2C+T-compiler&template=ice.md note: rustc 1.58.0-nightly (dd549dcab 2021-11-25) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu note: compiler flags: -C embed-bitcode=no -C codegen-units=1 -C debuginfo=2 --crate-type bin note: some of the compiler flags provided by cargo are hidden query stack during panic: end of query stack For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0412`. error: could not compile `playground` due to 2 previous errors ```

Thanks to the detailed error message I was able to quickly locate the issue, on this line: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/6d246f0c8d3063fea86abbb65a824362709541ba/compiler/rustc_ast_lowering/src/path.rs#L236 It is assumed that the last character of `snippet` will be a `)`, so using `snippet.len() - 1` as an index should be safe. However as we see in the input code, it is possible to enter that branch without a closing `)`, and it will trigger the panic if the last character happens to be multibyte.
